answers.text: prosecution by the state of wrongful acts

qas.question: What type of wrongful act will the state prosecute?

answers.text: acts which are considered to be so serious that they are a breach of the sovereign's peace

qas.question: Where are the majority of the U.S.'s crimes prosecuted?
Who focuses on things such as evading payment of federal income tax, mail theft, or physical attacks on federal officials, as well as interstate crimes like drug trafficking and wire fraud?
What is it called when the state is prosecuted?
Criminal law can be fixed by private parties bringing what?
Where are the minority of US crimes prosecuted?

plausible_answers.text: evading payment of federal income tax, mail theft, or physical attacks on federal officials

qas.question: What is an example of a tort?

context: <b5_0>Criminal law<b5_0/> involves the <a0_0>prosecution by the state of wrongful <a1_0>acts<a0_0/> which are considered to be so serious that they are a breach of the sovereign's peace<a1_0/> (and cannot be deterred or remedied by mere <b6_0>lawsuits<b6_0/> between private parties). Generally, <a2_0>crimes<a2_0/> can result in <b7_0>incarceration<b7_0/>, but torts (see below) cannot. The majority of the crimes committed in the United States are prosecuted and punished at the <a3_0><b8_0>state level<b8_0/><a3_0/>. <a4_0>Federal criminal law<a4_0/> focuses on areas specifically relevant to the federal government like <b9_0>evading payment of federal income tax, mail theft, or physical attacks on federal officials<b9_0/>, as well as interstate crimes like drug trafficking and wire fraud.
